metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 258-259 of 59 and 404 of 60

facts.text: Landlords' applications to authorities under Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 for possession of lands held by tenants were dismissed in four appeals.
In three cases (CAs 258-259/59 and 404/60), authorities refused possession because tenants paid arrears or were given time to pay, granting relief against forfeiture on equitable principles.
In fourth case (CA 259/59), held no default in payment of rent for three years, tenant entitled to statutory relief under s.25(1).
Bombay High Court refused to interfere under Art.227 by summary order without reasons.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court.
Tenants in default in paying rents for three years within s.14(1)(a)(i), due notices served terminating tenancies as per proviso to s.14(1). Date fixed for payment is 20th March each year.
In three cases, tenants not entitled to relief under s.25(1) due to three years default per s.25(2).
In CA 259/59, question whether tenant failed to pay rent for any year where prior relief granted under s.25(1); Revenue Tribunal held default merged in order.

legal_issues.text: Whether authorities under the Act can grant tenants relief against forfeiture on equitable principles where tenancy terminated under s.14 for three years rent default, denying landlord statutory right to possession under ss.14,25,29.
Whether s.29(3) empowers Mamlatdar to refuse possession order if justice requires, even after three years default.
Whether tenants entitled to relief under s.114 Transfer of Property Act despite s.3 of Bombay Act.
In CA 259/59, whether year of default where relief granted under s.25(1) counts as failure to pay rent for purposes of s.25(2) three years default.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tenancies terminated under s.14 for three years default; no equitable relief available against statutory termination; s.25(2) bars statutory relief; s.29(3) does not confer discretion to deny possession.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 ss.5,14,25,29

petitioner_arguments.text: s.114 Transfer of Property Act inconsistent with Bombay Act and inapplicable to agricultural leases.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Transfer of Property Act s.114; Bombay Act s.3

respondent_arguments.text: Relief against forfeiture on equitable principles, as courts reluctant to eject for rent default if arrears paid; s.29(3) allows order as justice requires.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sitaram Vithal Chitnis v. Gundu Satyappa Dhade; Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar

respondent_arguments.text: In CA 259/59, prior default under s.25(1) relief merges and cannot count for s.25(2).
Relief under s.114 Transfer of Property Act.

court_reasoning.text: Equity cannot annul statute; no relief against statutory termination under s.14 for three years default; landlord acquires statutory right to possession enforceable under s.29.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equity does not operate to annul a statute.

court_reasoning.text: s.29(3) empowers orders in terms of statute, not dehors it based on individual justice notions; authorities erred in refusing to enforce Act due to perceived hardship.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mamlatdar must discharge duty according to law.

court_reasoning.text: s.114 TPA inconsistent with Bombay Act ss.14,25 which limit relief to specified cases; inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relief only as per s.25(1), not broader equity.

court_reasoning.text: Prior s.25(1) relief does not wipe out default; it counts for s.25(2) 'any three years'; no merger.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Default remains despite relief against consequences.

court_reasoning.text: Overrules prior High Court decisions allowing equity relief post three years default.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Landlord has statutory right on termination.

holdings.text: No equitable relief against statutory tenancy termination for three years rent default; s.25(2) bars s.25(1) relief.
s.29(3) does not confer discretion to deny possession where Act entitles landlord.
s.114 TPA inapplicable due to inconsistency with Bombay Act.
Year with s.25(1) relief counts as default for s.25(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Sitaram Vithal Chitnis v. Gundu Satyappa Dhade
precedents_cited.citation: Special Civil Application No. 1695 of 1955, unreported
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court observation on equitable reluctance to eject for rent default if arrears paid; court disagrees with broad proposition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.29(3) justifies relief even after >2 years default; court holds wrongly decided.

precedents_cited.citation: Special Civil Application No. 2073 of 1955, unreported
precedents_cited.relevance: Default merges in s.25(1) order, not countable for s.25(2); court holds incorrect.
Justices cannot refuse statutory duty deeming law unjust.

precedents_cited.case_name: White and Tudors Leading Cases in Equity
precedents_cited.relevance: Equity never relieves against statute provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs tenancy termination for non-payment, relief limits, possession applications; landlord entitled to possession after 3 years default sans relief.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: s.114 relief inconsistent with Bombay Act; Chapter V applies only if not inconsistent and notified for ag. leases (not done).

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; orders of High Court, Revenue Tribunal and authorities set aside; respondent tenants directed to deliver possession of lands to landlords.

key_quotes.text: Every court of equity will be extremely reluctant to enforce an order of ejectment against a tenant when the only ground on which the landlord seeks ejectment is failure to pay rent.
key_quotes.speaker: Bombay High Court (in Sitaram case)
key_quotes.significance: Observation rejected by SC as too broad for statutory tenancies.

key_quotes.text: Equity does not operate to annul a statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle denying equitable relief against statutory rights.

key_quotes.text: Although, in cases of contract between parties, equity will often relieve against penalties and forfeitures, where compensation can be granted, relief can never be given against the provisions of a statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court (citing White & Tudors)

key_quotes.text: They have refused to carry out the Act because they felt that it worked hardship.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Critique of lower authorities' discretion exercise.

key_quotes.text: How can the default for the year merge in an order? No doubt relief has been given against the consequence of the default for the year, but that does not wipe out the default itself.
key_quotes.speaker: court
